activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: County Youth Lead
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Are you committed to delivering high quality care? Do you have experience working as part of a multidisciplinary team?

As a County Lead of Bristol, Avon & Somerset, you will be part of the establishment of a County St John Council to oversee and guide volunteer Community Networks aims to create a structured and supportive framework that empowers volunteers to operate more effectively and efficiently. By providing strategic leadership, coordination, and oversight, the council ensures that volunteer efforts align with community needs and priorities while avoiding duplication of services.

St John has embarked on a journey to achieve the goal of ensuring that every community and young person across the country is first aid confident.

We are looking for a leader with a passion for local volunteering and helping communities to inspire and support volunteers on this journey across your county

The post will also interact with relevant Communities of Practice to share learning, advice and best practice.

We are seeking individuals who are innovative in their approach, willing to explore new ideas, and able to adapt to a changing environment. You will be confident in driving technology-led solutions, while recognising the diverse needs and experiences of our volunteer community. We value those who can challenge existing ways of working respectfully and constructively, bringing forward creative approaches that enhance collaboration and impact, and minimise over-complication and disruptive processes. This is an opportunity to shape how we deliver outcomes across the county, ensuring our services remain relevant, inclusive, and effective for all the communities we serve.

The closing date for this vacancy is the 9th November 2025.

For more information please contact joe.cartwright@sja.org.uk

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Volunteer opportunity-DV advisor
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Volunteer opportunity-DV advisor 

Volunteer opportunity @MEWSO: Domestic Violence Advisor
Organisation: MEWSo (Middle Eastern Women and Society Organisation)
Location: Hybrid-London-based community work
Hours: Depend on availability
Salary: Competitive, based on experience and qualifications
Closing date: Rolling applications accepted
MEWSo is recruiting a committed and experienced volunteer Domestic Violence Advisor to support women from migrant, refugee, and minoritised backgrounds (particularly from Middle Eastern and South Asian communities) who are impacted by domestic abuse.
This is a “By and For” position, meaning the advisor must bring both lived or deep professional understanding of the community they serve. The successful candidate will join a small, dedicated team working to offer culturally sensitive, trauma-informed, and rights-based support to women navigating abuse, exclusion, and systemic barriers.
Key Responsibilities:
Provide direct advice, safety planning and support to women experiencing domestic abuse
Advocate for women navigating complex issues including No Recourse to Public Funds (NRPF), housing, and legal challenges
Work closely with local authorities, legal services, and housing teams
Maintain accurate case records and contribute to reports and impact evaluation
Support outreach and community education activities
 
Essential Criteria:
Formal qualification/certificate in domestic abuse support (e.g., IDVA or equivalent)
At least 2 years’ experience in supporting women affected by domestic abuse
Deep understanding of the experiences of migrant and refugee women, including barriers related to immigration status, language, and cultural pressure
Knowledge of NRPF policy and its implications for survivors
Strong engagement skills with Middle Eastern and/or South Asian communities
Ability to work confidentially and uphold safeguarding best practice
Excellent communication, organisational, and teamwork skills
Ideally recommend speak Arabic language 
Desirable:
Experience in multi-agency working or partnership settings
Understanding of trauma-informed approaches
If you believe in empowering women and want to make a difference in your community, we’d love to hear from you. To apply, please email your CV and a short cover letter explaining why you are a good fit for this role to: office@mewso.org

organizationSubDocument.name: Middle Eastern Women and Society Organisation
organizationSubDocument.description:
The Middle Eastern Women and Society Organisation (MEWSo) is a registered charity set up to support Middle Eastern, North African and Asian women in London. We reject every form of discrimination, inequality, and exclusion and aspire to a society where every woman lives in safety with equal opportunities.  We hope for a community in which diversity is considered an element of strength and not of division. 
Founded in 2010, MEWSo aims to:
- Protect and prevent violence against women in BAME communities through its various campaigns.
-Offer emotional and practical support through our advice services with particular emphasis on Domestic Violence and other Welfare issues (e.g. housing, benefits, disability and health, etc.)
-Help women empower themselves to rebuild their lives after experiencing trauma/hardship with workshops and projects catered to the needs of survivors.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Help set the record straight about diabetes by becoming an events volunteer. We are looking for Volunteers to attend local events within the district of Thanet (Kent). Ideally you'll have an excellent local knowledge and be able to suggest local events to our regional team and proactively seek out opportunities, so if you have some time to spare, this could be the role for you.

As an events volunteer, you will be working with Diabetes UK staff, talking to members of the public and handing out information about diabetes.

The events range from stands in shopping centres and high streets, to big events such as county shows. You don't need any previous knowledge or experience about diabetes or Diabetes UK. We give you all the information and support that you need

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Site Checks and Maintenance Volunteer (Roving Ranger Snettisham reserve)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
We need a team to help us maintain a presence on this remote reserve as much as possible. Essentially, we like to have volunteers on the reserve every day of the week. We are looking for people who can take on a regular shift walking the reserve,  keeping an eye out for maintenance issues while engaging with visitors in a positive and friendly manner. 

This role will include all of the following:
- Talking to members of the public about the reserve and the wildlife they might see.
- Supporting our 'Plovers in Peril' campaign to highlight the importance of shoreline habitats for beach nesting birds
- Checking paths, hides, benches and reporting issues back to the wider team. 
- Litter picking and sweeping hides
- Checking the car park machine and reporting issues back to the wider team
- Reporting inappropriate visitor behaviour. 
- Checking permits for special access parking area 
- Reporting visitor footfall 
- Supporting the wider team on high visitors days eg wader spectacles (dates and times for these will vary) by helping with parking, visitor flow and visitor engagement
- Where possible, this role is undertaken in buddy pairs

Training and support will be provided but for this role the following are essential: 

- Physically fit and able to be on your feet for 2-4 hours. 
- Good 'people skills', including diplomacy  
- Problem solving skills 
- Ability to work independently and as part of a team
- Good wildlife ID skills are advantageous but not essential

This is a really rewarding role set in a beautiful wildlife rich setting. The great outdoors will be your place of work and you will be able to take it at your own pace. By talking to visitors as you go along, you'll have the pleasure of helping people learn more about the reserve and the work of the RSPB, or just be a familiar friendly face to our regulars.  

You will be making a genuine contribution to nature conservation, and you might find it rewarding to safeguard nature in the area you are working to protect. You may be working alone in a remote setting or paired with another volunteer depending on our team capacity.

Our nature reserves are very special places for people and wildlife. Right across the UK the RSPB manages woodlands and wetlands, heathlands and meadows. A real mosaic of different kinds of habitats for a wide range of wildlife.

organizationSubDocument.name: RSPB
organizationSubDocument.description:
Working locally in the UK and around the world, we take a bird’s eye view of all the issues that the natural world can face. We look at the bigger picture, and focus in on the detail too. 

We’re in a nature and climate emergency, and individual species, habitats and landscapes are in jeopardy.

But we focus on hope. By working together with a renewed strength and purpose, we will provide solutions to ensure the natural world recovers, thrives and flourishes.

Our belief
We’re all connected by the wonder of nature. The health of the natural world is fundamental to the survival of all species and has a right to flourish. Nature is in crisis, by working together we can save it.

Our purpose
To advance the conservation of birds, wildlife and the natural world, by protecting and restoring habitats and landscapes, saving species, sharing knowledge and connecting people to nature.

The world we want to see
A shared world where wildlife, wild places and all people thrive. 

We’re all connected by the wonder of nature. The health of the natural world is fundamental to the survival of all species and has a right to flourish. Nature is in crisis, by working together we can save it.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Practical Reserve Work (Work Party Volunteer)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
**We are looking for adult Work Party Volunteers to make the regular commitment to join us on our Lochwinnoch reserve every Friday from 9.30am until 4pm.**

RSPB nature reserves are special places for people and wildlife and we rely on volunteers to keeps these habitats thriving and in good shape.

**This role is suitable for over 18’s and best suited to volunteers who live nearby. Our volunteers live within a 25 mile radius of our Reserve.**

It might seem like these wild places have always just been there. But quite often we have to work really hard to maintain habitats to be in the best condition for wildlife. We have lost a lot of wild landscapes, so the small places that we do have, need a bit of extra care.

As a Reserve Work Party Volunteer you will be joining a regular practical work party team to undertake practical habitat management tasks such as:

- Cutting and clearing vegetation.
- Maintaining and managing tools and equipment.
- Creating and maintaining visitor infrastructure, such as paths and benches. -Work in our habitats to improve the environment for wildlife.
- Following annual work plans.
- Following Health and Safety protocols.

If you enjoy being outdoors, meeting new people and hands on conservation work, then this role could be the perfect opportunity for you. This role does involve a reasonable amount of physical activity, so will enable you to keep your fitness levels high, as well as helping your mental health and wellbeing. You will have the satisfaction of knowing that you are making a genuine contribution to nature conservation, and you might find it rewarding to safeguard nature in the area you are working to protect.

We are a friendly and supportive team. If you are volunteering to learn new skills and gain knowledge about wildlife conservation work, you will find that our team will be more than happy to help you on that journey.

Please disregard the additional information, below, which states that this role is suitable for under 18s. Applicants must be over 18.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Practical Reserve Work (Assistant Warden Volunteer Placement)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
We are looking for a volunteer placement assistant warden at RSPB Middleton Lakes! Our placement opportunities help people gain the skills and experience needed to start a career in conservation. You will get to meet new people and help save nature too. Assistant warden volunteer placements bring in a variety of ideas, experiences and energy into our teams, it's so much more than just getting work done; we want to hear from you if you feel like you have the motivation and passion to save nature.

The aim of our placement opportunities are to build skills and to help people gain the experience necessary to assist in taking steps towards a career, primarily in conservation. We are looking for individuals who are interested in saving nature and with the energy to learn. We are not looking for experts in conservation, or even people with lots of experience, if you are new to the sector, changing careers or looking for a new challenge, this could be for you!

**Role description:**

This role forms a vital part of the wardening team, helping to implement our reserve management plan. This will involve:

- Learning on the job about practical habitat management of wetlands, woodlands and meadows.
- Maintenance of the reserve infrastructure such as fences, paths and benches which all need regular upkeep.
- Being responsible for the visitor standards of the reserve. Making sure the reserve is looking and functioning at its best for visitors.
- Leading other volunteers on regular work party days and being responsible for the corporate work party programme.
- Helping the warden manage the grazing and livestock on site which consists of Longhorn Cattle and Konik Ponies.
- Biological surveys in the Spring/Summer including breeding bird surveys, dragonfly, butterfly, amphibian/reptile, flora, and monthly WeBS bird counts in the winter.
- Keeping the reserve ticking over by completing the day-to-day jobs such as upkeep of the workshop/store areas, maintenance of the machines and tools, responding to any issues and resolving/fixing them.
- Supporting the warden with a variety of admin jobs including updating risk assessments, emergency action plans, COSHH and other records, mapping and biological data recording, recording visitor numbers, logging volunteer work hours.
- Working occasional weekend days meeting and greeting visitors from our visitor reception.

**The skills you need:**

We are looking for an enthusiastic and friendly person who likes a challenge! Previous conservation volunteering experience isn't essential, but every day can be different on reserves like Middleton lakes, so you will need to be flexible in your approach to your work. 

You must be happy to work outside in all weathers, doing what can be challenging physical work. There will be times when you are required to work by yourself through your own initiative. A willingness to work the occasional weekend and take time off in lieu is expected. A driving license is essential.

You must be able to get to and from Middleton Lakes for the duration of your placement as we are unable to offer onsite accommodation.

The RSPB runs an inclusive volunteer placement scheme, so whether you have just graduated, finished your A Levels and looking for voluntary experience in your gap year or you are looking for a change of career path, we welcome your application. However, we do ask that you meet the following requirements:

**You must:**

- be 18 years old or over
- be available for 12 months (3 days a week)
- be IT literate
- Have a full UK driving license
- Your time:
- Minimum: 3 days a week ideally Wednesday, Thursday and Friday but  can be flexible.
- Duration: 12 months (3 days a week)
- Application closing date: 20th October 2025
- Interview date: Week commencing 27th October 2025
- Period: Starting November 12th 2025


**What's in it for you?**

This is a fantastic opportunity to work on a new and developing nature reserve, delivering aims for the benefit of wildlife and people plus developing skills that could help you towards a career in conservation.

**You will gain:**

- An insight into how a nature reserve functions and how your work fits into the overall management.
- Development of skills necessary for a job in nature conservation.
- A good understanding of wetland ecology
- Development of species identification
- Development of working with others, leadership and communication skills
- A mentor who will work with you to aid a personal development plan and organise suitable training during the internship
- Access to our internal intranet
- An opportunity to make contacts within the RSPB
- Necessary training will be provided for routine nature reserve management.
- Training on CV writing, interview techniques and job applications
- A reference on the successful completion of your placement 

Our placements are designed to offer work experience. However, completing a placement unfortunately does not guarantee future employment with the RSPB. Placements can apply for our paid vacancies but for obvious reasons a placement will need to have proven themselves in their current role before their volunteering experience will assist an application for a paid post.

**Notes:**

Please note: Clicking 'more about this role' below brings up a more generic practical reserve work role description. Also, in attachments please refer to the attachment titled assistant warden volunteer placement. 

**The deadline for applications is Sunday 14th September 2025. Interviews will be the week beginning 22nd September 2025. **

All the training necessary and background information will be provided and since you'll be giving up your time, it's only fair that we offer to re-imburse your travel expenses (up to 25 miles). The RSPB is the country's largest nature conservation charity, inspiring everyone to give nature a home.

organizationSubDocument.name: RSPB
organizationSubDocument.description:
Working locally in the UK and around the world, we take a bird’s eye view of all the issues that the natural world can face. We look at the bigger picture, and focus in on the detail too. 

We’re in a nature and climate emergency, and individual species, habitats and landscapes are in jeopardy.

But we focus on hope. By working together with a renewed strength and purpose, we will provide solutions to ensure the natural world recovers, thrives and flourishes.

Our belief
We’re all connected by the wonder of nature. The health of the natural world is fundamental to the survival of all species and has a right to flourish. Nature is in crisis, by working together we can save it.

Our purpose
To advance the conservation of birds, wildlife and the natural world, by protecting and restoring habitats and landscapes, saving species, sharing knowledge and connecting people to nature.

The world we want to see
A shared world where wildlife, wild places and all people thrive. 

We’re all connected by the wonder of nature. The health of the natural world is fundamental to the survival of all species and has a right to flourish. Nature is in crisis, by working together we can save it.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Improve We Are Explorers CIC's Self-Sustainability
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
We Are Explorers CIC supports Neurodivergent LGBTQ+ young people and adults, offering safe, engaging, and person-led spaces for connection, learning, and self-expression. Our mission is to create a better, more inclusive world for Neurodivergent LGBTQ+ communities. Now, we want to take our impact to the next level—and we need your ideas, skills, and energy!

As a volunteer, you could:

Generate creative ideas for projects, services, and community initiatives

Help us find sponsors, donors, or new funding opportunities

Assist in creating a sustainable business plan or social enterprise strategy

Contribute skills in marketing, finance, or operations to make our CIC more self-sufficient

Support events, campaigns, or initiatives that raise awareness of our work

Who we’re looking for:

Enthusiastic, proactive people who want to make a real difference

Experience in business planning, fundraising, marketing, or event planning is a bonus—but passion matters most!

Creative thinkers ready to brainstorm and problem-solve

Time commitment: Flexible—one-off sessions or ongoing involvement welcome.

Location: We're based in Leigh, Greater Manchester, but are open to remote volunteering from people across the country!

Benefits:

Make a meaningful impact on an inclusive, growing organisation

Build skills in business development, social enterprise, and non-profit management

Join a supportive, creative team and expand your network

How to get involved:

Sign up through this platform or contact us at jam@weareexplorers.org. Let’s build something sustainable together!

organizationSubDocument.name: We Are Explorers CIC
organizationSubDocument.description:
At We Are Explorers, we create radically inclusive, joyful spaces for LGBTQ+ people — with a proud focus on Neurodivergent people. Because while 3.8% of the UK population identifies as LGBTQ+, a huge 25% of Neurodivergent people do. So why are so many queer spaces still inaccessible, overwhelming, or just not built with us in mind?

We exist to change that.

We were founded by Neurodivergent genderqueer person Jam Hirata-Smith (any pronouns) in 2021, while they were recovering from psychosis and navigating the often-overlooked gap for queer Neurodivergent spaces. What started as a youth group with just a handful of young people quickly snowballed into an organisation that now serves Neurodivergent LGBTQ+ adults and young people alike. Along the way, we also work to train schools, organisations, and individuals on the intersections of Neurodivergence and queerness.

Mainstream LGBTQ+ scenes can feel chaotic, loud, and exclusive. Neurodivergent spaces often overlook queer identities. We're building bridges between these worlds — and centering the people too often left out of both.

Autistic and otherwise Neurodivergent people experience gender and sexuality differently, and that truth deserves space, voice, and pride.

We believe:

Being fully yourself shouldn't come at the cost of burnout, masking, or erasure.

Inclusion means designing spaces that start with Neurodivergent needs — because when you do that, everyone benefits.

Queerness and Neurodivergence are not just valid — they’re vibrant, intertwined, and deserving of celebration.

We’re not here just to help people “survive” — we’re here to help people thrive.
We’re here to create spaces where softness is strength, stim toys are welcome, and identity is never a debate.
organizationSubDocument.purpose: We support Neurodivergent LGBTQ+ individuals by providing inclusive groups, services, advocacy, and training to improve accessibility, wellbeing, and empowerment. Our values are to be safe, engaging, and person-led.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Walking Group Volunteer - Tower Hamlets
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Do you have great social and inter-personal skills? Are you a good motivator and can engage with a range of service users? Then please read on! If you enjoy being outdoors and exploring new areas whilst walking, this is the perfect volunteering opportunity for you!

About Huddleston Close/ GUP
Huddleston Close and Grand union Place are supported accommodations catering for those experiencing on-going mental health challenges and complex needs. The service aims to facilitate the empowerment of service users towards independence and recovery through the development of life skills required to maintain independence; ultimately moving away from the institutional care that these service users may have faced.The service operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year with at least one member of staff onsite at all times and is split into two services running as one. 

Huddleston Close:
Huddleston Close caters to the high-support needs of service users. It offers accommodation for 11 individuals and focuses on facilitating service users’ access to community mental health services while developing life skills and the ability to maintain a tenancy successfully.
Grand Union Place:
Grand Union Place provides the step-down element of the service, catering to low support needs for 8 individuals and focuses on promoting as much independent living as possible for all service users.

Location: Tower Hamlets

organizationSubDocument.name: Hestia
organizationSubDocument.description:
At Hestia, we have been supporting adults and children across London in times of crisis since 1970. 2020 marked our 50th anniversary!

Last year we supported 14,007 men, women and children.
This includes victims of modern slavery, women and children who have experienced domestic abuse, young care leavers and older people. From giving someone a home, to helping them to get the right mental health support, we support people at the moment of crisis and enable them to build a life beyond a crisis. We are supported by nearly 950 volunteers across London who provide specialist skills such as art therapy, yoga, IT, gardening and cooking, as well as befriending and fundraising.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Show your support for a parent with a smile
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Getting out and about as a new parent can be a huge challenge and many new parents worry about what people might say if their baby starts crying in a public place or they need to feed their baby. 

You can take action and show your support for all new parents simply by sharing a smile, offering a kind word or holding a door open for a new parent struggling with a pram.

organizationSubDocument.name: NCT
organizationSubDocument.description:
We are the charity that supports people as they become parents. We're here for you through pregnancy, birth, and early parenthood.

Our charity has a proud 65-year history of creating transformative change in the lives of parents. We are a trusted voice, a reassuring presence and a strong advocate, campaigning on the issues that matter most.

Today, we are a membership charity and a strong community of volunteers, practitioners, peer supporters, staff, students, advocates, and campaigners. We have a huge opportunity to positively influence the experience of millions more people as they become parents and to shape a bright future together.

We share evidence-based information that parents can trust.

We listen to parents’ experiences and campaign to make things better.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Beyond Theory Learning : Long Term Volunteer Opportunities
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Beyond Theory is a youth-led, nonprofit initiative dedicated to providing free academic mentorship and personal development opportunities for students aged 11–16, particularly those from underrepresented or disadvantaged backgrounds.

Our programme connects students with passionate volunteer mentors who offer one-on-one and group sessions to improve academic confidence, develop study skills, and inspire future aspirations.

Beyond Theory’s mission is to bridge educational gaps and empower young people to reach their full potential, regardless of their circumstances. We collaborate with schools, charities, and community organisations to expand access to quality learning support and create lasting impact across the world.

We are looking for people to promote our organisation through outreach with local groups, schools and other organisations and social media. This is a volunteer opportunity and you will not be compensated, however certificates of completion and volunteer hours will be given. Please note, anyone under 16 can join as a mentee rather than a volunteer.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Write a Pen Pal letter to an African Child in Need!
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
In many African communities, poverty and tradition force children into adult roles far too soon, becoming parents, spouses, or laborers as early as age 12. Education is often cut short, and support is limited.

That’s why we created the Pen Pal Program , a simple yet powerful way for caring individuals like you to uplift these children with letters of hope, encouragement, and guidance. Just 20–30 minutes a week or month can make a lasting difference.

Your letters can touch on education, health, culture, the environment, or simply send warm wishes for important moments like exams, birthdays, Christmas, or Eid.

We’ll carefully match you with a child based on your availability and interests, along with their age, gender, dream job, favorite color, pets, and hobbies. Right now, more than 5,000 children are waiting to connect.

Whether you’re a student, parent, retiree, or part of a group, your words can inspire a brighter future.

Be the reason a child keeps believing. Join us today.

organizationSubDocument.name: Murphy charitable foundation Uganda
organizationSubDocument.description:
Murphy Charitable Foundation Uganda, established in 2018, is a registered humanitarian nonprofit organization based in Bukedea, Eastern Uganda. Its mission is to uplift marginalized rural communities by focusing on the needs of vulnerable children, youth, and women. The foundation is committed to providing equal access to education, healthcare, clean water, and livelihood opportunities to break the cycle of poverty. Its goal is to empower and enhance the lives of these individuals, believing that everyone deserves a chance to succeed.

Guided by Christian values, the foundation strives to implement effective and innovative solutions to pressing community issues. It operates at the grassroots level, planning and executing projects that address local challenges and promote sustainable development. Through collaboration with volunteers, donors, and community partners, the foundation aims to create lasting positive change in Uganda's most vulnerable populations.
organizationSubDocument.purpose: Murphy Charitable Foundation Uganda is a nonprofit that empowers vulnerable children, youth, and women in rural Uganda. Its purpose is to improve access to education, healthcare, clean water, and livelihood opportunities, breaking the cycle of poverty. Guided by our core values, we implements sustainable, community-driven projects in collaboration with volunteers and donors to create lasting positive change.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Legal support advising and checking
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Grimsby Community Energy (GCE) is seeking a volunteer solicitor to support our renewable energy projects by helping us finalise and manage legal agreements with host sites. This role is ideal for a qualified or recently retired solicitor with experience in commercial property or energy law, who wants to use their expertise to benefit a local, community-owned energy enterprise.
Key Responsibilities
•	Review, draft and finalise Power Purchase Agreements (PPAs), roof leases, and licences to occupy for host sites.
•	Advise on and prepare exclusivity agreements and related documentation.
•	Liaise directly with site hosts (schools, businesses, community buildings) to help progress agreements to signature.
•	Provide legal guidance on risk, obligations and compliance relevant to community-owned solar and battery storage projects.
•	Maintain accurate records of agreements and progress, supporting the project team in keeping documentation organised.
•	Advise on standard templates and best practice to streamline future agreements.
Skills and Experience
•	Qualified solicitor (or equivalent experience) with knowledge of property or energy contracts.
•	Familiarity with Power Purchase Agreements, leases, licences and exclusivity terms.
•	Strong communication and negotiation skills, able to engage positively with local organisations.
•	Organised and reliable, able to work independently and manage time effectively.
•	Commitment to community energy, sustainability and social value.

organizationSubDocument.name: Grimsby Community Energy - cooperative
organizationSubDocument.description:
Launched in 2016 by a committed group of people determined to deliver locally owned community energy. Award-winning Grimsby Community Energy is a community benefit society (CBS), a form of not-for-profit cooperative owned and run by local people that works for the benefit of the community.

Over the last eight years we have raised over £894,000 of investment to deliver renewable energy across Grimsby, Cleethorpes and North East Lincolnshire, installing 697kW of solar PV (photovoltaic) panels for community organisations, generating 1.14GWh of clean electricity and saving 279t of CO2.

This place-based approach to energy generation means local community organisations pay less for their energy and everyone who invests in Grimsby Community Energy has a vote in the running of our society. We are proud to have kept our promises to our investors and our community, ensuring we pay members a fair rate of return and creating wider community benefits, including creating jobs and establishing a community fund.

Our team have worked hard to develop our business but there is so much more we can do with your support. We appreciate grant funding from Co-operatives UK Booster Fund, NELC’s UK Shared Prosperity Fund, and the REACH Fund.

Our vision is to reach one megawatt of community owned solar PV by the end of 2025, and we won’t stop there, adding a second megawatt by 2030. So far, we have identified three new sites and one existing site, with more in the pipeline, that could join our solar community with your help.
organizationSubDocument.purpose:
Our mission is to reduce energy costs and CO2 emissions through community renewable energy projects.
Launched in 2016 by a committed group of people determined to deliver locally owned community energy. Award-winning Grimsby Community Energy is a community benefit society (CBS), a form of not-for-profit cooperative owned and run by local people that works for the benefit of the community.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Visitor Centre Welcome (RSPB Ynys-hir Reserve Ceredigion)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
The RSPB manages a big network of nature reserves which are havens for wildlife, and importantly very special places for people of all ages and abilities to visit and experience a nature rich landscape.

Nature is in trouble, there aren't many places left where wildlife can thrive, that is why we want to welcome more people to these places.

**[RSPB Ynys-hir](https://www.rspb.org.uk/days-out/reserves/ynys-hir)** is at the heart of the Dyfi valley covering 800 hectares of mixed habitats - oak woodlands, saltmarsh and reedbeds are just some of them. Our Visitor Centre is the Welcome hub for all our visitors. We are looking for volunteers to help in the centre, from welcoming people on arrival, explaining the various trails and what's about to see. 
You will need to be a people person, happy chatting and engaging with visitors of all ages and backgrounds ensuring that they have a warm wonderful experience at Ynys-hir. You will be expected to take transactions and contribute to the daily cleanliness of the centre, display and stock. 

Full training and support will be provide for this role but you do need to be a ‘people person’ and have good communication skills.

This is a really rewarding and enjoyable role. You will be working with a friendly team on a beautiful nature reserve, you will have the opportunity to make new friends and spend time outdoors. You will get to meet loads of new people in this role, enjoying conversation and helping people have a wonderful visit.

There is always the opportunity to learn new things and gain skills through volunteering, by working on a reserve, you'll naturally learn all about how nature reserves are managed and the wildlife that is found there.

This role is not suitable for under 18’s.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: School Governor - Bromley
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Do you want to be inspired by the impact of education?

What will you be doing?
Governing bodies are responsible for the strategic management of a school and will make decisions about a wide range of issues.

The core responsibilities involved are:
•	Ensuring accountability
•	Providing support and challenge to the schools senior leadership team
•	Monitoring and evaluating the school’s progress
•	Budgetary allocation and control
•	Shaping plans for school improvement and overseeing their implementation
•	Setting the school’s aims and values
•	Appointing senior members of staff including the Head Teacher
The governing body is usually split in to a small number of committees, each responsible for one area such as finance or pupil achievement. These committees will meet separately from the main governing body to discuss relevant issues in more detail. Discussion is then fed back at a full governing body meeting.
A school governing body is made up of representatives from the school, the parents, the local authority and the local community.

What difference will you make?
Governors make decisions that affect schools for years to come. Our recent impact survey found that our volunteers bring £9.9 million worth of value to schools each year, and 9/10 volunteers would recommend being a governor to a friend. 
As a governor, you can visit the school to gain an understanding of the culture and ethos and to get the most out of the role. You’ll also have the opportunity to meet children, parents, and teachers, and see the impact of your work first-hand.

What's in it for you?
Volunteering as a school governor is a challenging but rewarding role. As part of the governing board, you’ll:
•	help schools overcome challenges to ensure a bright future for children in your community
•	work collaboratively with people from different backgrounds, challenging your own perspective and broadening your network
•	gain experience outside of your job description and skills you can bring back to work

organizationSubDocument.name: Governors for Schools
organizationSubDocument.description:
We are an independent education charity that supports volunteers and state-funded schools across England and Wales.

Schools register their board vacancies with us, and we recruit, match and support volunteers to join them.

School governors work with the governing board to set the strategic direction of the school, hold the Head teacher to account and ensure money is well spent. They work together to ensure every child receives an excellent education and has the opportunity to thrive.

You don’t need to be a parent or education expert to volunteer as a governor. Schools require a combination of hard and soft skills to ensure their boards operate effectively. Whether you’re an experienced professional or embarking on the first stages of your career, we’ll work hard to match you with an appropriate school. If you’re over 18 and willing to devote some of your time to improving educational standards every month, we encourage you to apply.
organizationSubDocument.purpose:
Governors for Schools finds, places, and supports skilled volunteers as governors and trustees on school and academy boards.

We support schools across England and Wales to run effectively by finding high calibre governors to bring their skills and expertise to the table – and improve education for children.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Growing Places Mentor
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Volunteer with us at Shaw Trust Enterprises and help people in  your community grow. 

Our Growing Places are social enterprise projects, based on horticulture, that provide wellbeing support to adults and young people with a learning disability, autism, or mental health to become more independent, healthy, and connected within their community.

As a Growing Places Mentor, you will support people at our project to access this valuable time in their week by giving them the support and confidence they need to carry out tasks allocated to them. The people you help may have:
-	Mild to moderate learning disabilities, 
-	Autistic Spectrum Disorder, 
and/or  
-	Mild-moderate neurotic mental ill health (such as stress, anxiety, depression) 

The daily tasks they will take part in all help us make sure the enterprise runs smoothly and is a great place to be for both our Participants and customers. This could be anything from looking after the plants in stock to helping customers.

Some key duties include:

To provide mentoring and coaching support to participants of the service 

To support participants with daily activities such as growing plants, site maintenance, retail & customer service, and housekeeping.

To provide support both one-to-one and in a group setting as participants are taught new skills to enable them to become more independent, healthy, socially connected, and toward employment.

To help individuals to maintain written records relating to the tasks they completed that day.

organizationSubDocument.name: Shaw Trust
organizationSubDocument.description:
Volunteer with Shaw Trust and help create brighter futures for people in your community. 

Shaw Trust provides employment opportunities, skills development training, and health and wellbeing services across the UK. We operate charitable social enterprises and retail shops, and work alongside Shaw Education Trust, which runs a diverse chain of academy schools.

We add value to every service we deliver by investing back into community projects, such as our social enterprises, Community Hubs and national volunteering scheme.

Volunteers help us achieve our aim of empowering people and supporting them towards employment and/or helping with their mental health and wellbeing. They also help in our schools and Social Enterprises and they help us run our charity shops too.  

Shaw Trust volunteers are at the heart of everything we do. 

To find out more about becoming a Shaw Trust volunteer please email volunteers@shaw-trust.org.uk or visit shaw-trust.org.uk

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Let's Record Werrington's Wildlife (Peterborough)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
WILDLIFE FRIENDLY WERRINGTON: Recording the Flora for Werrington
We aim to record the plant species that grow wild in Werrington. We want everyone to help us record the plant species in each if the nine 1km squares that Werrington covers

1) Download the iNaturalist App. You can find out more at www.inaturalist.org

2) Under the Projects Tab, find Wildlife Friendly Werrington and press 'Join'

3) Whilst out on your local walks, via the app, take photos of the leaves and flowers you see (or upload your photos to the website)

4) The system will identify them for you and will record their location on the map

This is a GREAT way to find out more about the environment 
This will help guide local conservation management plans. We can’t conserve something if we don’t know it’s there!
This will help monitor change
This will add knowledge to national databases. The information you record will be deposited with the Botanical Society of British Isles.

organizationSubDocument.name: Werrington Neighbourhood Environment Group and Neighbourhood Council (Peterborough)
organizationSubDocument.description:
Werrington Neighbourhood Council was established over 50 years ago and its aims are to:

- Represent and promote the best interests of the inhabitants of Werrington,
- Act as a forum for local opinion on planning proposals, amenities, the local environment and the development of the local area
- To improve the environment of the area and the condition of life for its inhabitants by working in partnership with Peterborough City Council and other agencies.
- To establish and maintain a Neighbourhood Forum, for the express purpose of promoting and improving the social, economic and environmental well-being of Werrington.
organizationSubDocument.purpose:
Werrington Environment Group  works voluntarily to conserve and enhance Werriurban and natural environments for the wellbeing of residents and wildlife.

Together we can make Werrington an even better place for the benefit and wellbeing of Werrington residents and wildlife

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Practical Reserve Work (South Lakes Conservation Volunteer)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Join Our Conservation Volunteer Team!
Opportunities between Barrow and Kendal

Do you love being outdoors, care about wildlife, and want to make a positive difference in your local area? We’re looking for volunteers to help with a range of conservation and community projects across the beautiful parks and green spaces between Barrow and Kendal.

Whether you can give a few hours a month or more regularly, your time will help nature thrive — and you’ll pick up some great skills along the way!

What You Could Get Involved In:
- Litter picks to keep our parks clean and welcoming
- Removing old tree tubes to help young woodlands flourish
- Building bird nest boxes and bee banks to support wildlife
- Meadow raking and summer surveys (birds, invertebrates, meadows)
- Assisting with or leading guided walks — including popular bat walks!
- Helping engage school groups and local communities with nature
- Contributing ideas for future projects like a community orchard or improving lake water quality

Why Volunteer?
- Enjoy time outdoors and boost your wellbeing
- Learn new conservation skills and gain valuable experience
- Meet friendly, like-minded people
- Make a real difference to local wildlife and your community
- Flexible opportunities — you choose when and how you help
- No experience needed — just enthusiasm and a willingness to get involved!

If this sounds like something you’d enjoy, we’d love to hear from you. Together, we can create healthier habitats and greener communities across South Cumbria.

organizationSubDocument.name: RSPB
organizationSubDocument.description:
Working locally in the UK and around the world, we take a bird’s eye view of all the issues that the natural world can face. We look at the bigger picture, and focus in on the detail too. 

We’re in a nature and climate emergency, and individual species, habitats and landscapes are in jeopardy.

But we focus on hope. By working together with a renewed strength and purpose, we will provide solutions to ensure the natural world recovers, thrives and flourishes.

Our belief
We’re all connected by the wonder of nature. The health of the natural world is fundamental to the survival of all species and has a right to flourish. Nature is in crisis, by working together we can save it.

Our purpose
To advance the conservation of birds, wildlife and the natural world, by protecting and restoring habitats and landscapes, saving species, sharing knowledge and connecting people to nature.

The world we want to see
A shared world where wildlife, wild places and all people thrive. 

We’re all connected by the wonder of nature. The health of the natural world is fundamental to the survival of all species and has a right to flourish. Nature is in crisis, by working together we can save it.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Practical Reserve Work (Minsmere Work Party Volunteer)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
We are looking for work party volunteers to join us on our reserves. RSPB nature reserves are special places for people and wildlife and we rely on volunteers to keeps these habitats thriving and in good shape. This role is suitable for under 18s. 

It might seem like these wild places have always just been there. But quite often we have to work really hard to maintain habitats to be in the best condition for wildlife. We have lost a lot of wild landscapes, so the small places that we do have, need a bit of extra care.  

As a Reserve Work Party Volunteer you will be joining a regular weekday practical work party team to undertake practical habitat management tasks (on Tuesdays and Thursdays): 
- Cutting and clearing vegetation.
- Maintaining and managing tools and equipment. 
- Creating and maintaining visitor infrastructure, such as paths and benches. 
- Following annual work plans. 
- Following Health and Safety protocols. 

If you enjoy being outdoors, meeting new people and hands on conservation work, then this role could be the perfect opportunity for you. This role does involve a reasonable amount of physical activity, so will enable you to keep your fitness levels high, as well as helping your mental health and wellbeing. You will have the satisfaction of knowing that you are making a genuine contribution to nature conservation, and you might find it rewarding to safeguard nature in the area you are working to protect. 

We are a friendly and supportive team. If you are volunteering to learn new skills and gain knowledge about wildlife conservation work, you will find that our team will be more than happy to help you on that journey.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Practical Reserve Work (Campfield Marsh, Bowness On Solway)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Volunteers are the lifeblood of the RSPB. Their contribution to our work to save nature is vital. We are on the lookout for new volunteers at RSPB Campfield Marsh to help us in our effort to restore key habitats, including lowland wet grassland, lowland raised bog, and saltmarsh. In doing so, you will be aiding the RSPB achieve some of its key objectives: species recovery and climate change adaptation and mitigation. If you want to contribute to the saving of lapwing, redshank, curlew, and the marsh fritillary, please get in touch. If you want to play a key role in the restoration of wetlands crucial in combatting climate change, get in touch! 

The sorts of tasks you can expect to carry out whilst volunteering with us include:
• Using hand tools to create new habitat for wildlife and keep existing habitat in tip top condition
• Planting wildflowers for insects, including the rare marsh fritillary butterfly
• Working with the wardens and other volunteers to set up the temporary electric fence on the salt marsh; cutting and pulling vegetation around the electric fence to keep ground nesting birds safe
• In summer, surveying flora and fauna around the site to monitor the success of our habitat work
• Painting and fixing hides and fences, maintaining footpaths and boardwalks, for the benefit of visitors
• Keeping the garden at the visitor centre looking vibrant and healthy, for the benefit of insects and the enjoyment of our visitors.

Volunteering at RSPB Campfield Marsh brings with it a whole host of benefits: an improved connection with nature and people; opportunities to develop existing practical skills and learn new ones; a sense of purpose as you help to improve the state of nature on the reserve; better physical and mental health resulting from time spent being active in nature; and many more! If you are interested in pursuing a career in conservation, volunteering with us would be an ideal opportunity to gain vital hands-on experience. Full induction and training will be provided in the use of tools, site orientation, and survey skills on an ongoing basis so don’t worry if you have not used them before!

In short, we are looking for anyone with an interest in contributing to nature conservation on the reserve. Whoever you are, whatever your background, ability, or motivations, we are interested in hearing from and working with you. If you can make our weekly Thursday work party and if you are keen to work outdoors with others and possess a willingness to learn and lashings of positivity, please get in touch! Good physical fitness is advantageous, but we always endeavour to allocate the work accordingly and encourage everyone to go at their own pace.

Come and play your part in ensuring that the Solway Plain continues to consist of an array of wetland habitats playing host to an abundance of wildlife and storing huge quantities of carbon, slowing down and reversing climate change. You can make a big difference to nature!

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Retail Volunteer (Fairburn Ings)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Volunteers are the heart and soul of our shop and are essential in helping visitors to get everything they want from their time with us. We want our visitors to be welcomed with a warm smile and a friendly hello, in a well-kept, clean and full shop. By giving your time to this role you’ll be making a huge difference to the wildlife and habitat here at Fairburn Ings, as all our profits go straight back to helping nature. 

There's lots to keep you busy, so you’ll never be bored, here are some of the things you’ll be doing:
- Delivering excellent customer service, using the till and having a great knowledge of all our products so you can help each customer pick the right products. We will give you lots of training, but you need to be a real ‘people person’, chatty and friendly, approachable and with real enthusiasm for what we do.
- We have annual targets each year for our shop sales, so you’ll help us reach those targets. We also get mystery shoppers, so it’s important that you know the expected standards, to make sure we pass with flying colours!!
- We have lots of great events planned to let our visitors know about – each conversation is different so you can tailor each one and mention the things you think are relevant to that person.
- There is a small café as part of our shop, so we have plenty of checks to do each day to make sure we keep to our food hygiene standards.
- You’ll help us around opening and closing routines, with regular stocktaking, deliveries most days and there are various events you can get involved with too if you wish.
- You will talk to people about how they can support the RSPB and if you are interested, can even learn how to make new members for the RSPB, helping us gain more support and allowing us to do even more for nature.

This role is very rewarding. You get to meet lots of people, make new friends, and to top it all off you are working on a gorgeous nature reserve – what could be better? We need you and your enthusiasm to help our customers get the absolute best from their visit, if this sounds like you then get in touch now.

You can claim your travel expenses when volunteering, and you will be provided with a uniform and all the resources and training you need to undertake your role. You will have opportunities to learn new things and gain new skills and to learn about our reserves and the wildlife that is found here. You will need to undertake some essential online training, either at home or on site and you will be supported by a line manager and have lots of opportunity to discuss your role with them. 

**We also welcome applications from young people who are under 18 and wanting to gain volunteering experience. This is a great thing to add to your CV. Giving your time for something you believe in is a good thing to do, and makes you stand out against others when applying for jobs.**

This is an essential role to support the running of our shop, and therefore we do have fixed shifts to ensure we are able to operate as planned. These are: : 
Full day 9am to 4.30pm in winter and 5.30pm in summer,
Morning 9am to 1.00pm, 
Afternoon 1.00pm to 4.30pm in winter and 5.30pm in summer, 
Lunch cover 11.30am to 2.30pm. 
(full or half day shifts are available, we particularly need volunteers for Friday and Sunday afternoons)

Thank you for reading this description of the role. Clicking on ‘more about this role’ will take you to the generic ‘role profile’ for this opportunity. A role profile is the family to which an opportunity belongs and informs the vetting and training requirements. We particularly recommend taking note of the disclaimer.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Work Party Leader (Weymouth Wetlands)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
RSPB reserves are special places for people and wildlife. We need volunteers to help keep the habitats, paths, benches and fences in good shape. This rewarding role offers the chance to meet new people and make a positive impact for nature. 

Right across the UK the RSPB manages woodlands and wetlands, heathlands and meadows. A real mosaic of different kinds of habitats for a wide range of wildlife. We want to make sure they are special places for people too. We rely on volunteers to undertake practical work that keeps the habitats in good shape and to help maintain the paths and benches and fences. It is work that never stops. We need a work party leader to ensure that our volunteer group undertakes the right work at the right time and does this safely. 

RSPB Weymouth Wetlands (Radipole Lake & Lodmoor) are very unique, wild havens for a diverse range of species – bubbles brimming with wildlife amongst the hustle and bustle of Weymouth. Home to one of the healthiest populations of Cetti’s Warblers in the country, birders near and far are drawn to its curious mix of residents and visitors, including bearded tits, marsh harriers, bitterns, sedge warblers, golden plovers, bullfinches, bar-tailed godwits, and so much more. 

It might seem like these wild places have always just been there. But quite often we have to work really hard to maintain habitats to be in the best condition for wildlife. We have lost a lot of wild landscapes, so the small places that we do have, need a bit of extra care. 

As a Work Party Leader Volunteer you will: 

- Follow an annual management plan and work with the site manager to plan work party activities.
- Ensure all the tools and equipment needed for a work party are available and in good condition. 
- Follow relevant health and safety protocols and codes of practice to ensure work is carried out safely. 
- Ensure all volunteers understand the task and how to complete it safely. 
- Welcome and induct new volunteers. 
- Be the main point of contact for volunteers throughout the work party session and give direction and support as needed. 

Full training and support will be provided but we are looking for people with skills and experience in the following areas: 

- Essential.
- Leadership skills. 
- Excellent listener and communicator. 
- Willingness to direct a team of people so that they feel fully informed, supported and included. 
- May require some diplomacy skills on occasion. 
- Good attention to detail. 
- Well organised and methodical in approach. 
- Be comfortable reading and implementing risk assessment requirements. 

Beneficial:

- Some previous experience in practical work may be beneficial, however the work party leader we are looking for acknowledges the different perspectives thoughts and ideas within the team, and encourages an open and collaborative approach to problem-solving. 

You do not need to be a wildlife or nature expert to do this role. 

If you enjoy being outdoors, then this role could be the perfect opportunity for you. This role will involve a reasonable amount of physical activity, so will enable you to keep your fitness levels high, as well as helping your mental health and wellbeing. You will be making a genuine contribution to nature conservation, and you might find it rewarding to safeguard nature in the area you are working to protect. 

We are a friendly and supportive team, so you might make new friends too. 

If you are volunteering to learn new skills and gain knowledge about wildlife conservation work, you will find that our team will be more than happy to help you on that journey. 

In this role you will be helping others to succeed, especially as you induct and train volunteers who are looking to gain skills, this can be extremely rewarding.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: RSPB Team Member (Saving Slavonian Grebes – Remote Data Volunteer)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Help Save the Slavonian Grebe – Become a Data Volunteer

Slavonian Grebes are in trouble. Once thriving on over 30 lochs in Inverness-shire, their numbers have plummeted—from 80 pairs in the 1970s to just 20 pairs on 14 lochs in 2024. With support from the Nature Restoration Fund, we’re working to uncover the causes of this decline—and we need your help.

As a Data Volunteer, you’ll play a vital role in processing and analysing bird and habitat data collected during the 2025 breeding season. Tasks include digitising survey maps and forms, reviewing trail and underwater camera footage, and recording key observations. Your support will directly inform conservation efforts and help us understand the role of habitat, diet, and environmental pressures in the species’ decline.

This is a flexible, home-based role suitable for anyone in the UK with good attention to detail, IT skills, and a passion for nature. We ask for a minimum commitment of 15 hours between October and December 2025. You’ll receive full guidance and support from our friendly project team.

As a Data Volunteer you'll help with processing existing data, digitising handwritten maps and survey forms, and to review & analyse trail camera and underwater camera imagery. 

This role will include the following tasks and the team will provide full training and support: 
• Reviewing trail camera images, identifying and recording any birds or mammals or any human disturbance captured by the cameras. 
• Reviewing videos captured on underwater cameras and recording the type and number of fish appearing in the videos.  
• Digitising scanned copies of survey maps or forms by entering the data into spreadsheets or databases.  
• This role may be shared between several volunteers assigned to the role 

You will receive guidance and support from the project team, but we are ideally looking for people with:
• Good communication skills
• Attention to detail and the ability to focus on a task
• Ability to accurately transfer data from a handwritten format to a digital format.  
• IT skills, including creating and managing spreadsheets. 
• Good organisational skills

This role is primarily a home based role, it can be undertaken from anywhere in the UK and you can mostly carry out the role in your own time. You can carry out this role using your own laptop or computer, equipment can be provided if required. 

You will receive written instructions and guidance from project staff, they will be on hand to discuss the tasks with you via video call or phone call. Project staff will give guidance and training, we ask that volunteers are able to commit at least 15 hours of their time to this role between October and December 2025. 

Make a real impact for nature—join us in protecting one of Scotland’s most iconic birds.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Maintaining Flatford Wildlife Garden in the best condition for wildlife and to inspire visitors to make their own gardens welcoming to nature takes a lot of effort and many hands. We’re looking for someone to join the Thursday work party team at Flatford Wildlife Garden to help keep on top of basic garden maintenance tasks.

- Maintaining flower beds
- Cutting and clearing vegetation. 
- Creating and maintaining visitor infrastructure, such as paths

If you enjoy being outdoors, meeting new people and hands on conservation work, then this role could be the perfect opportunity for you. address.street: Rathlin West Light Seabird Centre, Rathlin West Light Seabird Centre, Rathlin Ireland, Ballycastle, Co Antrim, BT54 6RT, United Kingdom

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: RSPB Team Member (Biosecurity Island Incursion Team Member)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Rathlin Island is home to Northern Ireland’s largest seabird colony, with over 200,000 birds, including the largest Guillemot colony in the UK and Ireland and over 1,000 Puffins. However, these populations are under serious threat from invasive non-native predators—rats and ferrets—which prey on seabird eggs, chicks, and adults. 

Introduced unintentionally in the 1800s (rats) and deliberately in the 1980s (ferrets), these predators have significantly impacted Rathlin’s wildlife. For example, Puffin numbers have halved since 1985, with chick survival rates dropping from 75% in healthy environments to just 33%. The Corncrake, another vulnerable ground nesting bird, is also at risk. Rathlin remains the only breeding site for Corncrake in Northern Ireland. 

An incursion is when a non-native invasive mammal has recently spread to the island but has not yet established a population. As part of the shared protection plans, we are building a network of trained volunteers to respond to an incursion and react rapidly to any reported invasive predator and remove this threat as quickly as possible.  

**We will provide training and host occasional team days**, but you will **only be called upon in the event of an incursion**. We do not expect that everyone will be available all the time, but by having a large network of volunteers we aim to ensure that we have enough when needed. 

Depending on your skill set and interests there may be other tasks you can help the team with such as more regular surveillance checks, reviewing trail camera footage, constructing wooden rodent motels, or helping with maintenance and stock takes of hub equipment. Awareness raising is an important way of improving biosecurity, so any way you can help with this, be it through communicating with your friends/family or at a larger public event would be much appreciated.  

As a LIFE Raft biosecurity volunteer, you’ll be part of something big – a team of amazing and dedicated people who donate their time, energy, talent and skills to help birds and other wildlife. We will help you gain skills and give you an invaluable insight into essential biosecurity work.  

**What you will be doing**

- Routinely checking the permanent monitoring loops to see if there are any signs of rats. This means checking monitoring station based around Rathlin in the routes most likely to have a rat incursion.  

- Contacted if an incursion has occurred, likely at short notice.  

- Assist with practical on-the-ground incursion conservation work. This will involve the active control of invasive predators, by use of traps or rodenticide if there is an incursion. 

- You will be involved in setting out and checking equipment (monitoring/poisoning/trapping equipment) in the first 48hrs of any incursion response. 

*If you are not a Rathlin resident it will be possible to carry out day trips, you may also be required to stay on island, if necessary, accommodation will be provided. You will be working alongside other volunteers, RSPB NI staff and key stakeholders as a team.*

Other tasks you may have the opportunity to get involved with if you are interested include helping at events, reviewing trail camera footage, constructing wooden rodent motels, or helping with maintenance and stock takes of hub equipment. 

**The skills you need and the skills you can bring**

The Island incursion role is varied, and the list below is an example of the type of skills required but not all are necessary, there are other aspects to the role which may be more suited to you. Everyone will bring a range of valuable skills so come and have a chat with our Biosecurity Manager to see if this role is for you. 

- Follow procedures required for the removal of invasive predators and learn necessary monitoring skills required.  

- Able to attend required training and follow health and safety requirements. Work as part of a team of 3-8 people to carry out the main tasks.  

- Be flexible and adaptable to change. 

- Have a friendly nature and be able to communicate effectively with people.  

- Physically able to embark and disembark boats– including small tenders and where no hard slipway is present.  

- Comfortable moving across rugged terrain in all weathers, including slippery rocks, steep slopes and at a safe distance from cliff edges.  

- Be able to carry equipment across rugged terrain – as a minimum 5 – 10kgs (this would include personal equipment, food/drink, and incursion response materials).  

- Able to camp, if necessary and cook as part of a rota for other team members. 

- Maintain any equipment provided. 

- Carry out responsibilities in an environmentally aware manner, ensuring as little damage to the environment as possible. Our aim is to ensure all resources are used effectively and efficiently.  

**What's in it for you** 

Biosecurity on Rathlin is a shared sense of responsibility to ensure the island remains invasive predator free long after the LIFE Raft project is completed, by being involved you will: 

- Be helping to save some of our most iconic seabirds in one of the most spectacular locations in Northern Ireland and enable some ground nesting birds to breed and increase in numbers. 

- Be part of a team to help maintain the legacy and socio-economic benefits of maintaining an invasive predator free status along with the residents of Rathlin 

- Gain valuable experience and training in implementation of biosecurity measures  

- Meet and work with other passionate volunteers and staff expert in the biosecurity field  

If you volunteer for LIFE Raft, the RSPB will reimburse you for travel and subsistence expenses, we will provide you with the equipment, training and any PPE needed for you to complete the role.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: RSPB Team Member (Biosecurity Island Monitoring Team Member)
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Rathlin Island is one of Northern Ireland's most treasured wildlife havens, home to internationally important seabird colonies and unique native species. To help keep the island free from invasive predators like rats - which can devastate nesting birds - we are building a network of trained biosecurity volunteers. This is your chance to play a vital role in safeguarding Rathlin's natural heritage while spending time in one of the most beautiful and diverse places in the country.

**What you will be doing**

You will be starting out as a LIFE Raft volunteer and this role will then become a biosecurity volunteer. You will carry out monthly checks of one of five biosecurity loops, checking for signs of rodent activity. You'll monitor tracking tunnels, bait stations, chew blocks, and record your findings to help us respond quickly if rats are detected. **We'll provide full training** and you will be apart of occasional team days for refreshers, updates and the chance to connect with staff and other volunteers.

Depending on your availability and interests there may also be opportunities to:

- Review trail camera footage for signs of wildlife or rats
- Construct or maintain monitoring stations
- Help with equipment stock-takes and record keeping
- Support awareness, whether by chatting to friends and family or helping at public events

**Skills you'll need**

You don't need previous experience in conservation or biosecurity - just:

- A keen eye for detail and willingness to learn
- A love for nature and the outdoors
- A reasonable level of fitness (some loops involve uneven ground)
- Ability to commit to one check per month, with flexibility

We don't expect everyone to be available all the time - that's why we're building a large, flexible team to ensure coverage when it's needed most. 

**What's in it for you**

- Be part of a vital conservation effort that makes a real difference 
- Learn new skills and gain hands on experience in biosecurity monitoring
- Spend time outdoors in a stunning natural environment 
- Meet like-minded people 
- Receive full training and support 

If you are not a Rathlin resident it will be possible to carry out day trips. However, you may be required to stay on the island and accommodation will be provided in this event.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Christmas Concert Ushers - Missing People
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Get into the festive spirit by volunteering at X Factor's G4’s Christmas Concert. Hear wonderful renditions of Christmas classics, even join in on a few tunes yourself, all while supporting the charity Missing People. This is a fantastic opportunity to volunteer at a truly enjoyable evening so don’t miss out.

Please register through the application form here - https://forms.volunteero.org/view/a7f14263-69dc-4ad8-9d40-f33f0bac4de0

Volunteers will be acting as ushers, showing guests their seats on arrival. You will also be helping to collect donations during intervals and at the end of the night, standing around the venue holding a bucket or tap to donate card machine.

For each venue, we also need a Lead Volunteer. This involves collecting and counting the cash donations at the end of the night and transferring to the charity the following day. You would receive specific instructions for this.

No training is needed for the role. You will receive a simple email briefing a few weeks in advance, and a full briefing from the team on your arrival on the night.

The event is from 19:30 – 21:30, but we’d ask for you to arrive at the venue from 18:00 and expect to finish at 22:00. Dates across November & December, around UK.

organizationSubDocument.description: Missing People offers a lifeline for the 250,000 people who run away and go missing each year in the UK. For those left behind, we provide specialised support to ease the heartache and confusion, and help search for their missing loved ones.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Living Well at Home Volunteer
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Do you live in our Croydon area and could you visit patients at home, coaching and enabling them to achieve goals?

Why we need your help

To enable us to provide a rehabilitation and enablement service to patients in their own homes.
To promote independence and support to help someone to achieve their goal
Increase patients’ self-confidence and ability to self-manage their difficulties or symptoms.

organizationSubDocument.name: St Christopher's Hospice
organizationSubDocument.purpose:
We are proud to offer world class palliative and end of life care to everyone who needs it, whenever or wherever that may be. We are also here for the people closest to you.

We passionately believe in the words of our founder, Dame Cicely Saunders, who said: “You matter because you are you and you matter until the last moment of your life.” That means we’ll listen to your story, adapt our treatments and advice to suit your particular needs, and we won’t stop until we can give you the best possible support.

The hospice itself is a friendly, vibrant place, and as unlike a traditional hospital as we can make it. But rest assured, our medical and nursing care is excellent and our clinical teams are highly professional and devoted to doing their best for you.

However, as we often say, we’re more than just a hospice. We are proud of our community programmes that offer practical, emotional and spiritual support to over 7,500 people in the local area, most of whom we will help to continue living at home. If you’re one of them, we are ready to help you too.

We are a place for everyone.

activityDefinitionSubDocument.title: Compassionate Neighbours
activityDefinitionSubDocument.description:
Be the difference on your doorstep.
Compassionate Neighbours are trained volunteers offering friendship, support and listening ear to people living in their local community, sometimes with serious, long-term or terminal illness who often struggle with loneliness.

By popping round for a cup of tea or a friendly chat once a week you can make a world of difference. You will be a good listener, kind and have a genuine interest in other people.

As a Compassionate Neighbour Volunteer you’ll not only gain new skills, confidence, and social networks; you’ll be making a difference in your local community.

Full training and support is provided. Training for our next intake will be held at the Hospice on the following dates:
Wednesday 21 & Friday 23 May 2025, 9.30am – 3.30pm

If you are unable to attend those, we have scheduled training later on:
Saturdays 21 & 28 June 2025, 9.30am – 3.30pm

For further details about this role please contact the Volunteering Team on 01372 461856 or email volunteering@pah.org.uk

please apply here:  https://www.pah.org.uk/volunteer-roles/compassionate-neighbour/

organizationSubDocument.name: Princess Alice Hospice
organizationSubDocument.description:
Princess Alice Hospice is a local charity dedicated to providing free, high-quality compassionate care and support for patients, their families and carers. We care for people with cancer and other illnesses living in a large part of Surrey, south west London and Middlesex.

We aim to enable all patients to have the best possible quality of life to the end, responding quickly to their needs and wishes. We recognise that family, carers and friends have needs of their own and we are here to provide them with support, comfort and advice at every stage of illness and after death

Through our education and research activities we also work to improve end of life care

Founded by our local community, fundraising and community support are crucially important to our continued work as a charity
organizationSubDocument.purpose: Princess Alice Hospice is here to provide free, holistic palliative care for patients with advanced illness and those approaching the end of their lives. We aim to reach out to more people by delivering outstanding care, nurturing compassionate communities, sharing our knowledge and expertise and influencing the debate around death and dying​.
